title-group.article-title: A proteolytic complex targets multiple cell wall hydrolases in Pseudomonas aeruginosa

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Carboxy-terminal processing proteases (CTPs) occur in all domains of life. In bacteria, they have been associated with virulence, but their roles are poorly understood. One is the CtpA protease of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is required for type III secretion system function, and for virulence. Here we show that CtpA works with a previously uncharacterized binding partner to degrade four substrates. The accumulation of at least one of these substrates is required for ctpA null mutant phenotypes. All of the substrates are predicted to hydrolyze peptidoglycan cross-links, suggesting that the CtpA complex might be a central control hub for peptidoglycan hydrolysis. When considered with other findings, we propose that this will emerge as a widespread mechanism used by diverse bacteria to control some of their peptidoglycan hydrolases. This is significant, given the links between CTPs and virulence in several pathogens, and the importance of peptidoglycan remodeling to almost all bacterial cells.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacterium that accounts for over 10% of healthcare associated infections with an identifiable cause, and even more in the intensive care unit (Driscoll et al., 2007). It is a versatile pathogen responsible for both acute and chronic infections (Turner et al., 2014). In acute infections, P. aeruginosa utilizes a type III secretion system (T3SS) to export proteins into host cells, where they interfere with host cell signaling, immune function, and cause cytotoxicity (Hauser, 2009). In chronic infections, such as those occurring in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients, P. aeruginosa is thought to form biofilms resilient to clearance by antibiotics and the immune response (Wagner & Iglewski, 2008, Clark et al., 2015). Importantly, the emergence of antibiotic resistant strains is increasing, making this pathogen a top priority for the discovery of new therapeutic targets (Moore & Flaws, 2011).

Proteases are important for the virulence of many bacterial pathogens. Some P. aeruginosa proteases are secreted to act on or within host cells, whereas others regulate the virulence characteristics of the bacterial cell itself (Lyczak et al., 2000). One intriguing family of proteases is the carboxy-terminal processing proteases (CTPs), which are found in all three domains of life. CTPs belong to the S41 family of serine proteases with a serine/lysine catalytic dyad (Rawlings et al., 2010). As the name suggests, they are believed to target substrates close to their C-terminus (Hara et al., 1991, Keiler et al., 1995). A well described CTP occurs in plant chloroplasts and cyanobacteria, where it cleaves a component of the photosystem II reaction center to process it into its active form (Satoh & Yamamoto, 2007, Che et al., 2013). Gram-negative bacterial CTPs are found exclusively in the periplasmic compartment and have been implicated in cleaving proteins associated with cell envelope function and integrity (Hara et al., 1991, Kumru et al., 2011). Some CTPs have also been associated with virulence, but mostly by poorly defined mechanisms (Mitchell & Minnick, 1997, Bandara et al., 2005, Lad et al., 2007, Bandara et al., 2008, Seo & Darwin, 2013, Carroll et al., 2014, Deng et al., 2014). Indeed, despite their widespread conservation, our knowledge of exactly how CTPs function, and which proteins they cleave, is quite limited.

The model organism Escherichia coli has only one CTP, known as Prc or Tsp (Hara et al., 1991, Keiler et al., 1995). prc null mutants have altered cell morphology, increased drug and osmotic sensitivity, and altered virulence (Seoane et al., 1992, Wang et al., 2012). Prc has been proposed to process penicillin binding protein 3 (PBP3/FtsI), an essential peptidoglycan transpeptidase required for cell division (Hara et al., 1991). More recently another Prc substrate was discovered, the peptidoglycan hydrolase MepS, which cleaves peptide cross-links between the glycan chains of peptidoglycan (Singh et al., 2012, Singh et al., 2015). These substrates suggest that Prc plays a role in controlling different aspects of peptidoglycan metabolism. However, Prc has also been shown to cleave incorrectly folded polypeptides in the periplasm, suggesting that it is also has a broader role in protein quality control (Silber et al., 1992, Keiler et al., 1995, Keiler et al., 1996).

P. aeruginosa has a homolog of E. coli Prc, with the two proteins sharing over 40% amino acid identity and belonging to the CTP-1 subfamily, according to the MEROPS database (Rawlings et al., 2010). In contrast to its role in E. coli, P. aeruginosa Prc has been proposed to degrade mutant forms of the antisigma factor MucA, which occur in strains isolated from cystic fibrosis patients. MucA degradation induces the AlgT/U regulon, causing constitutive production of the exopolysaccharide alginate (Reiling et al., 2005, Sautter et al., 2012). Prc has also been implicated in activating the AlgT/U regulon in strains with a wild type MucA protein (Wood et al., 2006). However, Prc has not been shown to cleave any form of MucA directly.

Unlike E. coli and many other bacteria, P. aeruginosa has two CTPs. The second, known as CtpA, is smaller than Prc and in a different subfamily (the CTP-3 subfamily; Hoge et al., 2011, Seo & Darwin, 2013). CtpA is required for T3SS function, and a ctpA null mutant is less cytotoxic to cultured cells and attenuated in a mouse model of acute pneumonia (Seo & Darwin, 2013). In this study, we have discovered that CtpA forms a complex with an uncharacterized protein, which we have named LbcA (lipoprotein binding partner of CtpA). LbcA is required for CtpA activity in vivo, and promotes its activity in vitro. We have also identified four substrates of CtpA, all of which are uncharacterized proteins predicted to cleave the peptide cross-links within peptidoglycan. The accumulation of one of these substrates can explain all ctpA null mutant phenotypes described so far. We propose that LbcA•CtpA is a proteolytic complex that limits the activity of multiple peptidoglycan hydrolases by degrading them. Based on these and other findings we also argue that many bacterial CTPs might be similarly controlled by partner proteins as part of a widespread mechanism to control peptidoglycan hydrolase activity. This is significant because peptidoglycan cross-link cleavage must be carefully controlled to avoid lethal rupture, but little is known about how this is achieved. Furthermore, there are few molecules more important in bacterial disease, and its treatment, than peptidoglycan.

sec.title: Identification of the CtpA binding partner, LbcA
sec.p: We modified the chromosomal ctpA gene to encode tandem epitope tags at the C-terminus of CtpA (CtpA-FLAG-His6). This was done in a strain encoding wild type CtpA, and in a strain encoding CtpA with the catalytic serine mutated to alanine (S302A). The rationale was that after tandem affinity purification, substrates might be trapped by the inactive CtpA-S302A version. These experiments were done with or without in vivo formaldehyde cross-linking prior to protein purification with nickel agarose followed by anti-FLAG affinity gel. However, the results were similar +/- formaldehyde cross-linking (data not shown) and so only the results from an experiment without cross-linking are shown in Figure 1A.

caption.p: Identification of the CtpA interaction partner PA4667/LbcA. (A) Tandem affinity tag purification. Proteins were purified from detergent solubilized lysates of the wild type strain (CtpA), or derivatives encoding CtpA-FLAG-His6 or the proteolytically inactive CtpAS302A-FLAG-His6. Purification was done with nickel agarose (Stage 1) followed by anti-FLAG M2 agarose resin (Stage 2). Samples were separated on a 12.5% SDS polyacrylamide gel, which was stained with silver. Molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are labeled on the right-hand side. (B) Immunoblot analysis of detergent solubilized lysate, and Stage 1 and 2 purified samples, prepared as in panel A. LbcA and CtpA were detected with polyclonal antisera. Strains in which CtpA or CtpA-S302A were not tagged with FLAG-His6 served as negative controls. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side.

sec.p: SDS-PAGE revealed that both versions of CtpA co-purified with similar and abundant amounts of a protein running between 50 and 75 kDa markers (Fig. 1A). This protein was identified by mass spectrometry as the uncharacterized PA4667 protein (PAO1 strain designation). A polyclonal antiserum was raised against PA4667 and it confirmed that PA4667 co-purified with the epitope tagged CtpA and CtpA-S302A proteins (Fig 1B). PA4667 is predicted to be an approximately 63 kDa outer membrane lipoprotein with eleven tetratricopeptide (TPR) repeats. The TPR motif is a degenerate 34 amino acid sequence that occurs in tandem arrays and mediates protein-protein interactions (Blatch & Lässle, 1999). However, PA4667 does not appear to be a CtpA substrate because its level is similar in ctpA+ and ΔctpA strains (see below). This is consistent with PA4667 co-purifying equally well with active or inactive CtpA (Fig. 1). Therefore, we will refer to PA4667 as LbcA, (lipoprotein binding partner of CtpA).

sec.title: ΔlbcA and ΔctpA mutants have common phenotypes
sec.p: LbcA interacts with CtpA but it does not appear to be a CtpA substrate. Therefore, we hypothesized that LbcA might be required for CtpA function. Despite repeated attempts we could not construct an ΔlbcA in frame deletion mutant. However, we could make ΔlbcA::aacC1 mutants in which most of the lbcA gene is replaced by aacC1, encoding gentamycin resistance. This was possible only if aacC1 was in the same orientation as lbcA. Global RNA sequencing has shown that lbcA is in an operon with the downstream lolB and ipk genes, which are both essential (Wurtzel et al., 2012). Therefore, we speculate that the aacC1 promoter helps to express lolB and ipk, and that our inability to make a ΔlbcA in frame deletion might be due to reduced lolB-ipk expression (e.g. destabilizing the operon transcript, or removal of an internal promoter within lbcA).

A ΔctpA mutant has a defective T3SS (Seo & Darwin, 2013). Therefore, we compared the ability of ctpA and lbcA null mutants to export the T3SS effector proteins ExoS and ExoT into culture supernatants. Both mutants exported less ExoS and ExoT than the wild type (Fig. 2A). The ΔlbcA::aacC1 phenotype was complemented by an lbcA+ plasmid, supporting the contention that it was due to loss of LbcA rather than altered expression of downstream genes. We also complemented the ΔctpA mutation with wild type CtpA but not the proteolytically inactive CtpA-S302A, as shown previously (Fig. 2A; Seo & Darwin, 2013).

caption.p: ΔctpA and ΔlbcA mutants share common phenotypes. (A) T3SS function. Wild type, ΔctpA or ΔlbcA strains contained the tac promoter expression plasmid pVLT35 (vector), or derivatives encoding CtpA, CtpA-S302A or LbcA as indicated. TSB growth medium contained 1mM EGTA to induce T3SS activity, and 10 µM IPTG to induce the tac promoter of the complementing plasmids. Cell free supernatants derived from equivalent amounts of cells were separated on a SDS-PAGE gel, which was stained with silver. The region with the abundant T3SS effectors ExoT and ExoS is shown. (B) Surface attachment. The same strains as in panel A were incubated in glass test tubes at 30°C without agitation for 8 hours. The growth medium contained 10µM IPTG to induce the tac promoter of the complementing plasmids. Bacterial cells attached to the glass at the air/liquid interface were stained with crystal violet (purple rings). The stain was dissolved in ethanol and quantified by measuring absorbance at 540 nm. All strains were tested in triplicate and error bars represent the standard deviation from the mean.

sec.p: Recently we have discovered that a ΔctpA null mutant has a phenotype in an assay where bacteria are grown in static liquid culture and then cells attached to the test tube surface are visualized by staining with crystal violet (O'Toole & Kolter, 1998). After an 8 hour incubation, the ΔctpA mutant had attached robustly whereas the wild type had not (Fig. 2B). This appears to be an accelerated surface attachment phenotype because after a 16 hour incubation, the wild type strain caught up so that its surface attachment was indistinguishable from the ΔctpA mutant (data not shown). We tested if the lbcA null mutant shares this phenotype and found that it did (Fig. 2B). Furthermore, the ΔlbcA and ΔctpA mutants were complemented by plasmids encoding the wild type proteins, but the ΔctpA phenotype was not complemented by CtpA-S302A. All strains grew at similar rates in the conditions used in these assays (data not shown), showing that the accelerated surface attachment of the mutants was not due to faster growth.

ctpA and lbcA null mutants share defective T3SS and accelerated surface attachment phenotypes (Fig. 2). An lbcA null mutant is also sensitive to overproduction of a secretin protein, which was the phenotype by which we originally discovered a ctpA null mutant (data not shown; Seo & Darwin, 2013). All of these findings support the hypothesis that LbcA might be required for CtpA proteolytic function.

sec.title: Evidence that LbcA recruits CtpA to the outer membrane
sec.p: If CtpA interacts with LbcA, a predicted outer membrane lipoprotein, then this should tether CtpA to the membrane. However, we and others concluded that CtpA is a soluble periplasmic protein because it was released from cells by osmotic shock (Hoge et al., 2011, Seo & Darwin, 2013). Even so, a significant amount of CtpA was not released in our experiment (Seo & Darwin, 2013). Perhaps the harsh osmotic shock can disrupt LbcA•CtpA complexes. Indeed, we have now found that the amount of CtpA released by osmotic shock varies between experiments. However, a significant amount of CtpA is always retained in the spheroplasts, and this is more pronounced when cultures are harvested at a lower optical density (OD) than before (OD 600nm of 1 instead of 1.5; data not shown). Therefore, to address the influence of LbcA, we osmotically shocked lbcA+ and ΔlbcA strains that had been grown concurrently to OD 600 nm of 1 (Fig. 3A). In the lbcA+ strain, most CtpA was not released by osmotic shock, whereas a soluble periplasmic control protein was released completely. However, in the ΔlbcA mutant, most CtpA was now released by osmotic shock. This supports the hypothesis that LbcA influences the localization of CtpA, perhaps by tethering it to the outer membrane.

caption.p: LbcA promotes retention of CtpA in spheroplast and membrane fractions. (A) Osmotic shock fractionation. Total cell lysate (whole cells), as well as spheroplast and periplasm fractions generated by osmotic shock, were separated by SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose and proteins detected with polyclonal antisera. PA0943 is a soluble periplasmic protein control, and PA4068 is a cytoplasmic spheroplast-retention control (Seo & Darwin, 2013). (B) Fractionation of lysed cells. Cells were lysed by two passages through a French pressure cell and separated into soluble and insoluble (Membrane) fractions by ultracentrifugation. Samples derived from equivalent amounts of cells were separated by SDS PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose, and proteins detected with polyclonal antisera. PA0943 is a soluble protein control and OprF is an insoluble outer membrane control.

sec.p: To test this further we used an approach that separates cells into soluble and insoluble fractions by French press lysis and ultracentrifugation. Interestingly, LbcA was found in both the soluble and insoluble fractions (Fig. 3B). We do not yet know if this has any physiological significance, or if it might be an artifact resulting from some LbcA disengaging from the membranes during sample processing. Regardless, the important finding is that in an lbcA+ strain, CtpA fractionated similarly to LbcA, being distributed between soluble and insoluble fractions. However, in an ΔlbcA mutant, CtpA was found only in the soluble fraction (Fig. 3B). Once again, these data are consistent with the LbcA•CtpA interaction serving to localize some CtpA to the outer membrane.

sec.title: Isolation of putative CtpA substrates
sec.p: All the preceding experiments suggested that CtpA and LbcA form a complex, with both proteins required for CtpA to target its substrates. Therefore, we reasoned that the best approach to search for those substrates would be to purify only the CtpA that is part of a LbcA•CtpA complex. To achieve this, we modified our tandem affinity tag approach by putting the His6 tag on CtpA or CtpA-S302A, and the FLAG tag on LbcA. The tagged proteins were encoded by separate expression plasmids and produced at near physiological levels as judged by immunoblot (data not shown). To improve the probability of success, the plasmids were introduced into a ΔctpA mutant to increase the abundance of uncleaved substrates in the strain producing the CtpA-S302A-His6 trap.

Strains were grown in T3SS inducing conditions and treated with formaldehyde to covalently cross-link associated proteins. Proteins were purified using nickel agarose followed by anti-FLAG affinity gel, and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and silver staining (Fig. 4A). Purification of the LbcA•CtpA complexes was successful, and some proteins appeared to be enriched with LbcA•CtpA-S302A compared to LbcA•CtpA (Fig. 4A). We analyzed two independent purification samples from each strain by mass spectrometry. 101 proteins were present in both LbcA•CtpA-S302A samples, but neither of the LbcA•CtpA samples (Fig. 4B and Supplemental Table 1). Most of these were detected in low amounts. However, for our initial follow-up, we focused on the most abundant as judged by peptide spectrum matches (PSMs), the uncharacterized PA0667 protein (Fig. 4B). PA0667 has a predicted Sec-dependent signal sequence, a LysM peptidoglycan-binding domain, and an LytM/M23 peptidase domain. It shares these domains with, and is 35% identical to, the E. coli MepM protein, a DD-endopeptidase that cleaves the DAla-meso-DAP peptide cross-links of peptidoglycan to facilitate cell elongation (Singh, 2012). Therefore, we will refer to PA0667 as MepM.

fig.label: Figure 4.

caption.p: Identification of MepM as a putative substrate of the LbcA•CtpA proteolytic complex. (A) Tandem affinity tag purification. Proteins were purified from detergent solubilized lysates of ΔctpA strains. All strains had a plasmid encoding LbcA-FLAG as well as a second plasmid encoding untagged CtpA (negative control), CtpA-His6 or the proteolytically inactive CtpA-S302A-His6. Purification was done with nickel agarose followed by anti-FLAG M2 agarose resin. Samples were separated on a 12.5% SDS polyacrylamide gel, which was stained with silver. Molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are labeled on the left-hand side. An irrelevant region of the gel between the marker and sample lanes has been removed. (B) Scatter plot of proteins identified by mass spectrometry after purification from strains encoding CtpA-S302A-His6. Data are the average peptide spectrum matches (PSM) and sequence coverage from duplicate purifications from strains with CtpA-S302A-His6. Each point represents a different protein. All proteins plotted were detected in both of the LbcA•CtpA-S302A-His6 purifications but neither of duplicate LbcA•CtpA-His6 purifications. (C) Immunoblot analysis of equivalent amounts of whole cell lysates of wild type, ΔctpA and ΔlbcA strains. All strains contained an arabinose-inducible expression plasmid encoding MepM-FLAG. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side. MepM-FLAG was detected with anti-FLAG monoclonal antibodies and CtpA and LbcA were detected with polyclonal antisera. (D) Detection of endogenous MepM. Immunoblot analysis of equivalent amounts of whole cell lysates of wild type and ΔctpA strains. Strains contained the tac promoter expression plasmid pVLT35 (-), or derivatives encoding CtpA or CtpAS302A as indicated. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side. MepM, CtpA and LbcA were detected with polyclonal antisera.

sec.title: Evidence that MepM is a proteolytic substrate of the LbcA•CtpA complex in vivo
sec.p: To quickly test if MepM might be an LbcA•CtpA substrate, we constructed a plasmid encoding arabinose inducible MepM-FLAG and introduced it into wild type, ΔctpA and ΔlbcA strains. MepM-FLAG synthesis was induced by including 0.02% arabinose in the growth media, and equivalent amounts of each strain were analyzed by anti-FLAG immunoblot. This revealed that MepM-FLAG was undetectable in the wild type strain, whereas it was abundant in ΔctpA and ΔlbcA mutants (Fig. 4C). To analyze endogenous MepM we raised a polyclonal antiserum against the purified protein. This antiserum was unable to detect MepM in the wild type strain, but once again it revealed that MepM accumulated in a ΔctpA mutant (Fig. 4D). Furthermore, the accumulation of MepM was reversed by complementing the ΔctpA mutant with a plasmid encoding wild type CtpA, but not by the proteolytically inactive CtpA-S302A (Fig 4D). Together, all of these data support the hypothesis that MepM is cleaved by CtpA in vivo, and that this is also dependent on the presence of LbcA.

sec.title: Deletion of mepM suppresses ΔctpA mutant phenotypes
sec.p: If the role of CtpA is to degrade/inactivate MepM, then some or all ΔctpA phenotypes might be caused by MepM accumulation. If so, a ΔmepM mutation should suppress those ΔctpA phenotypes. To test this, we introduced a mepM in frame deletion mutation into wild type and ΔctpA strains and then surveyed their phenotypes (Fig. 5).

fig.hwp:rev-id: xref-fig-5-1 xref-fig-5-2 xref-fig-5-3 xref-fig-5-4 xref-fig-5-5 xref-fig-5-6 xref-fig-5-7 xref-fig-5-8 xref-fig-5-9
fig.label: Figure 5.

caption.p: The YsaC secretin co-immunoprecipitates with Psp effector proteins. (A) F(pspA-lacZ) operon fusion expression. All strains had the chromosomal pspA operon controlled by the tac promoter and either pspB, pspC, or neither (untagged) modified to encode a C-terminal 3´FLAG epitope tag (FLAG) as indicated. Strains also contained empty araBp expression plasmid pBAD33 (- YsaC) or a derivative encoding YsaC-His6 (+ YsaC). Error bars indicate the positive standard deviations from the means. (B) Immunoblot analysis of input lysates and co-immunoprecipitates (Anti-FLAG IP) derived from the + YsaC strains used in panel A. PspA, PspB, PspC and FtsH were detected with polyclonal antisera and YsaC-His6 was detected with anti-His6 monoclonal antibodies.

sec.p: First, we monitored the export of ExoS and ExoT into culture supernatants by the T3SS. The ΔmepM mutation did not have a strong effect on the amount of ExoS/T in the supernatant, although their levels in the ΔmepM mutant were slightly increased compared to wild type, a trend that was consistent in independent experiments (Fig. 5A and data not shown). The ΔctpA mutant exported lower amounts of ExoS/T, as before. However, this phenotype was suppressed by the introduction of a ΔmepM mutation, with the ExoS/T secretion profiles of wild type and ΔctpA ΔmepM strains being indistinguishable (Fig. 5A). Furthermore, when mepM was expressed from a plasmid in the ΔctpA ΔmepM mutant it reduced T3SS function (Fig 5A). These data support the hypothesis that the accumulation of MepM was responsible for the defective T3SS phenotype of the ΔctpA mutant.

We also investigated cytotoxicity towards CHO-K1 cells by measuring their release of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) into the cell culture supernatant. This is a well-established model for studying the toxic effect of the P. aeruginosa T3SS on eukaryotic cells (Lee et al., 2005). Indeed, we reported previously that a ΔctpA mutant is less cytotoxic towards CHO-KI cells (Seo & Darwin, 2013). Here, we found that the cytotoxicity phenotypes of the ΔctpA, ΔmepM and ΔctpA ΔmepM strains were fully consistent with their T3SS phenotypes (Figs. 5A and B). ΔmepM did not affect cytotoxicity, ΔctpA reduced it, and this reduction was suppressed in the ΔctpA ΔmepM double mutant (Fig. 5B). These data further suggest that MepM accumulation in a ΔctpA mutant causes the defective T3SS and the reduced cytotoxicity to CHO-K1 cells.

Finally, we tested the effect of the ΔmepM mutation in the surface attachment assay. The ΔmepM mutation suppressed the accelerated surface attachment phenotype of the ΔctpA mutant, and this suppression could be reversed by the introduction of a mepM+ plasmid (Fig. 5C). Therefore, all of these findings suggest that the various phenotypes of a ΔctpA null mutant require MepM. As expected, we have also found that a ΔmepM mutation suppresses these same phenotypes of a ΔlbcA mutant (data not shown). The simplest explanation for all of this is that the phenotypes of LbcA•CtpA-defective strains are the result of increased hydrolysis of peptidoglycan cross-links, which we tested next.

sec.title: Peptidoglycan cross-linking is reduced in a ΔctpA mutant
sec.p: The peptidoglycan compositions of wild type and ΔctpA strains were characterized by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS). The peptidoglycan repeat unit in P. aeruginosa consists of the disaccharide GlcNAc-MurNAc with a pentapeptide stem L-12 Ala-D-iso-Gln-m-Dap-D-Ala-D-Ala attached to the lactic moiety of MurNAc (Fig. 6A). The disaccharides are joined by β1-4 glycosidic linkages to form the glycan chain. The glycan chains are cross-linked via a peptide bond between the sidechain of m-DAP in an acceptor stem of one repeat unit, to the carbonyl carbon of a penultimate D-Ala in a donor stem of a neighboring glycan chain. To characterize peptidoglycan compositions, isolated cell walls were digested with mutanolysin, which cleaves the β1-4 glycosidic linkage between MurNAc and GlcNAc, resulting in muropeptide fragments with intact cross-links. Muropeptide ions detected by LC-MS were identified by matching the observed m/z values to the corresponding entries in a muropeptide library generated in silico using an in-house program. Forty-seven unique muropeptide ion species from the wild type, and thirty-three from the ΔctpA mutant were selected for the analysis. Muropeptide fragments were quantified by integrating the extracted ion chromatogram (XIC) of the selected muropeptide ion (Chang et al., 2017a, Chang et al., 2017b, Chang et al., 2017c). The normalized summed integrals of muropeptides from the XIC ion current were categorized based on the cross-link number per muropeptide fragment (Fig. 6B). Muropeptide fragments larger than trimers were not observed, and the most abundant muropeptides were peptidoglycan dimers. Representative mass spectra of monomer, dimer, and trimer from the wild type are shown in Figure 6, and the chemical structure and calculated masses for these selected peptidoglycan monomer, dimer, and trimer are in Supplementary Figure S1.

fig.hwp:rev-id: xref-fig-6-1 xref-fig-6-2 xref-fig-6-3 xref-fig-6-4 xref-fig-6-5 xref-fig-6-6
fig.label: Figure 6.

caption.p: Changes in peptidoglycan composition of a ΔctpA mutant. (A) Chemical structure of peptidoglycan-repeat unit in P. aeruginosa. The disaccharide of peptidoglycan-repeat unit is shown with two modifications: O-acetylation of MurNAc at C6 position and amidation of D-iso-Glu in PG-stem to to D-iso-Gln. The inter-peptide bridge structure in P. aeruginosa is m-Dap. A schematic representation of a peptidoglycan-repeat unit is shown as a figure inset with the disaccharide as gray-filled circles, the amino acids in the pentapeptide stem as open triangles, and the inter-peptide bridge structure as a line. The polymerized peptidoglycans are cross-liked by forming a peptide bond between the sidechain of m-Dap from one repeat unit to the carbonyl carbon of penultimate D-Ala of a peptidoglycan stem from a neighboring glycan chain. (B) The mutanolysin-digested muropeptide fragments were characterized by LC-MS. Forty-seven unique muropeptide ions from the wild type and thirty-three from the ΔctpA mutant were identified from LC-MS and each muropeptide was quantified by integrating the extracted ion chromatogram (XIC) of the selected muropeptide ion. Peptidoglycan dimers are the most abundant muropeptides found in both wild type and ΔctpA mutant with percent compositions of 87.30% ± 1.34% and 75.85% ± 3.90%, respectively. Muropeptide fragments larger than trimers were not observed. The p-values for the differences between wild type and ΔctpA strains for monomers, dimers, and trimers based on the t-test are 0.0001, 0.0003, and 0.0216, respectively. (C) The calculated peptidoglycan cross-linking efficiency (ρCL) for wild type and ΔctpA mutant are 50.86% ± 0.98% and 49.46% ± 0.18%, respectively, with a p-value of 0.0038. All errors bars represent 95% confidence interval (n = 3). Representative mass spectra of monomer (D), dimer (E), and trimer (F) are shown with the XICs as insets. The corresponding chemical structures are in Supplementary Figure S1.

sec.p: This analysis revealed that the cell walls of the ΔctpA mutant had a reduced concentration of peptidoglycan dimers compared to the wild type (87.30% ± 1.34% and 75.85% ± 3.90% for wild type and ΔctpA mutant, respectively; Fig. 6B), and a concomitant increase in monomers. This is consistent with decreased peptidoglycan cross-linking efficiency (ρCL) in the ΔctpA mutant. The calculated ρCL for wild type and ΔctpA mutant were 50.86% ± 0.98% and 49.46% ± 0.18%, respectively (Fig. 6C). The reduced peptidoglycan cross-linking in the ΔctpA mutant is small. However, the accompanying increase in trimers and monomers, indicates altered peptidoglycan biosynthesis. Furthermore, a relatively small effect was expected because a ctpA mutant grows well, had very few phenotypes in a Biolog Phenotype MicroArray (Seo & Darwin, 2013), and is not notably sensitive to low osmotic conditions (data not shown). Regardless, these data are consistent with the phenotypes of LbcA•CtpA-defective resulting from accumulation of a peptidoglycan cross-link hydrolase.

sec.title: LbcA enhances CtpA-dependent degradation of MepM in vitro
sec.p: The in vivo experiments suggested that MepM might be a direct proteolytic substrate of CtpA, and that its cleavage also requires LbcA (Fig. 4). To test this, we purified C-terminal hexahistidine tagged versions of CtpA, CtpA-S302A, LbcA and MepM by nickel-agarose affinity chromatography. Equimolar amounts of these proteins were incubated for 3 hours at 37°C (Fig. 7A). MepM was stable when incubated alone. However, in the presence of CtpA the amount of MepM decreased, suggesting that CtpA had degraded it. Furthermore, when MepM was incubated with both CtpA and LbcA it became undetectable, which is consistent with LbcA enhancing CtpA-dependent degradation (Fig. 7A). Importantly, there was no degradation of MepM when it was incubated with CtpA-S302A alone, or with CtpA-S302A + LbcA. This supports the contention that the S302A mutation destroys CtpA proteolytic activity, that the degradation of MepM was due to CtpA and not a contaminating protease activity, and that LbcA cannot degrade MepM itself. Therefore, these in vitro assays support the hypotheses that MepM is a direct substrate of CtpA, and that LbcA enhances the proteolysis.

fig.hwp:rev-id: xref-fig-7-1 xref-fig-7-2 xref-fig-7-3 xref-fig-7-4 xref-fig-7-5 xref-fig-7-6
fig.label: Figure 7.

caption.p: In vitro proteolysis of MepM. (A) CtpA degrades MepM and is enhanced by LbcA. 2 µM of the indicated C-terminal His6-tagged proteins were incubated for 3 h at 37°C. Samples were separated on a 12.5 % SDS PAGE gel, which was stained with coomassie brilliant blue. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side. (B) Time course. Reactions contained 2 µM of CtpAHis6 and MepM-His6 either without (-LbcA) or with (+ LbcA) 2 µM of LbcA-His6. Reactions were terminated at the indicated time points by adding SDS-PAGE sample buffer and boiling. As a negative control, the same experiment was done using PA3787 in place of MepM. Samples were separated on 12.5 % SDS PAGE gels, which were stained with coomassie brilliant blue. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side. PA3787 ran at the midway point between marker proteins of 25 and 37 kDa, which were below and above the region of the gel shown in the figure.

sec.p: To further test the role of LbcA we monitored the degradation of MepM by CtpA over time, +/- LbcA (Fig. 7B). This demonstrated that the rate of CtpA-dependent degradation of MepM was faster in the presence of LbcA. We also incubated CtpA +/- LbcA with another LytM/M23 peptidase domain protein, PA3787. However, PA3787 was not degraded significantly throughout the time course of the experiment (Fig. 7B). This indicates that CtpA has substrate specificity, even amongst related proteins.

These in vitro experiments support the characterization of MepM as a direct proteolytic substrate of CtpA. They also suggest that LbcA catalyzes CtpA-dependent proteolysis. This offers an explanation for the requirement of LbcA in vivo, and is consistent with ΔctpA and ΔlbcA mutants having common phenotypes. CtpA is a member of the C-terminal processing protease family. However, our in vitro assays suggest that it degrades MepM rather than only processing its C-terminus in a single cleavage event. We did not observe any stable fragments in the in vitro assays, and we also have not detected stable truncated MepM fragments in vivo with our MepM antiserum (data not shown). Of course, it remains possible that CtpA cleaves close to the C-terminus of MepM, but that it also cleaves the reaction product(s) in a serious of C-terminal proteolytic events resulting in complete degradation.

sec.title: The LbcA•CtpA complex also degrades some other predicted peptidoglycan cross-link hydrolases
sec.p: Based on PSM, the MepM substrate was the most abundant protein that co-purified with the LbcA•CtpA-S302A trap (Fig. 4B). Remarkably, the three proteins with the next highest PSM values are also known or predicted peptidoglycan hydrolases (PA1198, MltD and RlpA). PA1198 belongs to the NlpC/P60 peptidase family and is homologous to E. coli MepS (Singh et al., 2012). In E. coli, MepS is as DD-endopeptidase involved in cell elongation, and it targets the same peptide cross-links as MepM (Singh et al., 2012). MltD (PA1812) and RlpA (PA4000) are lytic transglycosylases that attack the glycan chain of peptidoglycan (Bateman & Bycroft, 2000, Lee et al., 2013). RlpA contributes to maintenance of cell shape, and to daughter cell separation in P. aeruginosa (Jorgenson et al., 2014).

CtpA cleaves one peptidoglycan hydrolase (MepM). Therefore, we considered the possibility that it might cleave the other three that co-purified abundantly with the LbcA•CtpA-S302A complex. To test this, we constructed plasmids encoding arabinose inducible C-terminal FLAG tagged versions of PA1198, MltD and RlpA, and introduced them into wild type and ΔctpA strains. Synthesis of each FLAG-tagged protein was induced with arabinose, and cell lysates were analyzed by anti-FLAG immunoblot. Like MepM-FLAG, PA1198-FLAG was undetectable in the wild type strain, whereas it became abundant in a ΔctpA mutant (Fig. 8A). We extended the analysis for PA1198 to study the effect of an ΔlbcA mutation, which also caused PA1198 accumulation (Fig. 8A). Therefore, PA1198 behaves the same as MepM, suggesting that is also a substrate of the LbcA•CtpA complex. However, MltD-FLAG and RlpA-FLAG were easily detectible in wild type strains, and did not accumulate in a ΔctpA mutant (Fig. 8A). Although a trivial explanation is possible (e.g. the FLAG tag inhibited cleavage), this suggests that MltD and RlpA are not CtpA proteolytic substrates. An intriguing possibility for their abundant co-purification with the LbcA•CtpA-S302A trap is that they form a complex with one or more CtpA substrates (see Discussion).

fig.label: Figure 8.

caption.p: Identification of additional substrates of the LbcA•CtpA complex. (A) In vivo analysis. Immunoblot analysis of equivalent amounts of whole cell lysates of wild type and ΔctpA strains, and also of ΔlbcA strains for proteins that accumulated in the ΔctpA mutant. All strains contained an arabinose-inducible expression plasmid encoding C-terminal FLAG-tagged versions of the indicated proteins. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side. Test proteins were detected with anti-FLAG monoclonal antibodies, and CtpA and LbcA were detected with polyclonal antisera. Each box has analysis of proteins in related families, as indicated at the top. Only those proteins with names in bold face accumulated in the ΔctpA mutant. (B) In vitro analysis. 2 µM of the indicated C-terminal His6-tagged proteins were incubated for 3 h at 37°C. Protein only indicates incubation of the test substrate alone. PA3787-His6 was used as a negative control. Samples were separated on a 15 % SDS PAGE gel, which was stained with coomassie brilliant blue. Approximate positions of molecular-mass-marker proteins (kDa) are indicated on the left-hand side.

sec.p: Two predicted peptidoglycan hydrolases accumulate in ΔctpA and ΔlbcA mutants, the LytM/M23 peptidase family member MepM and the NlpC/P60 family member PA1198 (Fig. 8A). Therefore, in addition to the pull down approach to find substrates, we also used a biased approach by screening other putative P. aeruginosa peptidoglycan hydrolases. Again, this was done by constructing plasmids encoding arabinose inducible C-terminal FLAG tagged versions. The candidates included three more members of the LytM/M23 peptidase family that MepM is in (PA3787, PA4404 and PA5551), two members of the LytM/M23 family with predicted defective peptidase domains (PA3623/NlpD and PA5363; these dLytM proteins regulate amidases; Uehara et al., 2009, Uehara et al., 2010, Yakhnina et al., 2015), and three more members of the NlpC/P60 family that PA1198 is in (PA0639, PA1199 and PA1844/Tse1). We also tested PA2272 (PBP3A) and PA4418 (PBP3), two homologs of E. coli penicillin binding protein 3 (PBP3/FtsI). In E. coli, PBP3 was identified as a substrate of its only carboxy-terminal processing protease, Prc/Tsp (Hara et al., 1991). Most of these candidates were present at similar levels in wild type, and ΔctpA strains, suggesting that they are not CtpA substrates (Fig 8A). However, PA1199 and PA4404 were not detected in the wild type but accumulated in the ΔctpA mutant. Again, we extended the analysis for these two proteins to an ΔlbcA mutant, and they also accumulated in this strain (Fig. 8A). Therefore, the biased approach of screening putative peptidoglycan hydrolases identified two more candidates as putative LbcA•CtpA proteolytic substrates.

To test if the PA1198, PA1199 and PA4404 proteins that accumulated in the ΔctpA and ΔlbcA mutants are proteolytic substrates, we purified C-terminal hexahistidine tagged versions and tested them in vitro. All three were degraded most effectively when incubated with LbcA and CtpA, as we had observed with MepM (Figs. 7A and 8B). As expected, there was no degradation when the proteins were incubated with LbcA and CtpA-S302A (Fig. 8B).

CtpA degrades four predicted peptidoglycan hydrolases. Two belong to the LytM/M23 peptidase family and are homologous to E. coli MepM (PA0677/MepM and PA4404), and two belong to the NlpC/P60 family and are homologous to E. coli MepS (PA1198 and PA1199). Significantly, all four are predicted to cleave the same peptide cross-link bonds of peptidoglycan. Breaking these cross-links poses an obvious danger to the bacterial cell. Therefore, the LbcA•CtpA complex might be the central control hub used by P. aeruginosa to regulate this activity. Our discovery of multiple substrates also raises an intriguing question. If four or more peptidoglycan hydrolases can accumulate in a ΔctpA mutant, why did removing only one of them (MepM) suppress the phenotypes? Possible explanations are considered in the Discussion.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: P. aeruginosa CtpA is required for T3SS function, cytotoxicity, and virulence (Seo & Darwin, 2013). Other bacterial CTPs have also been associated with virulence (Baumler et al., 1994, Mitchell & Minnick, 1997, Bandara et al., 2005, Lad et al., 2007, Bandara et al., 2008, Hernandez et al., 2013, Carroll et al., 2014, Deng et al., 2014). However, in most cases the mechanisms remain largely unexplored, and very few CTP substrates have been identified. Our goal was to address this deficiency for CtpA in P. aeruginosa. We discovered that CtpA forms a complex with an uncharacterized outer membrane lipoprotein, LbcA, and that both proteins are required for CtpA-mediated proteolysis in vivo and in vitro. We also identified four substrates of this complex, all of which are predicted to be hydrolases that target the cross-links between peptidoglycan chains. Therefore, the LbcA•CtpA complex might be a major control hub used by P. aeruginosa to regulate peptidoglycan cross-link hydrolysis.

An exciting parallel exists between the LbcA•CtpA complex we have discovered, and the NlpI•Prc complex in E. coli. Prc is a CTP, and NlpI is an outer membrane lipoprotein with TPR motifs, and together they degrade the peptidoglycan hydrolase MepS (Singh et al., 2015). Therefore, the similarities between LbcA•CtpA and NlpI•Prc are obvious. However, there are also important differences. Prc and CtpA are evolutionarily divergent, differing in size by approximately 30 kDa and belonging to different CTP subfamilies. Although NlpI and LbcA are both outer membrane lipoproteins containing short TPR motifs, their primary sequences are not similar and LbcA is twice the size of NlpI. Recently, the structure of the E. coli NlpI•Prc complex was solved, showing that an NlpI homodimer binds two Prc monomers to create docking sites for the MepS substrate (Su et al., 2017). Although the LbcA•CtpA complex in P. aeruginosa could have similarities to this, we suspect that its stoichiometry and functioning will have differences, due to the different sizes of the proteins involved and their evolutionary divergence. Regardless, it is important that two very different CTPs, and two very different lipoproteins, form complexes in two significantly divergent bacterial species to degrade peptidoglycan hydrolases. This suggests that this could be an extremely widespread phenomenon. Therefore, we speculate that a new paradigm will emerge in which many bacterial CTPs work with partner proteins, and that one of their most important conserved functions will be to target cell wall hydrolases.

The most abundant protein trapped by the inactive LbcA•CtpA-S302A complex was PA0667, which we named MepM due to its homology with E. coli MepM (Fig. 4B). By analogy to its E. coli homolog, MepM is predicted to be a DD-endopeptidase that cleaves the D-Ala-m-DAP cross-links between the peptide chains of parallel glycan strands within peptidoglycan (Singh et al., 2012). Our finding that LbcA•CtpA degrades MepM suggests that MepM activity will increase in a ΔctpA mutant. Consistent with this, peptidoglycan cross-linking was reduced in the ΔctpA mutant (Fig. 6), and a ΔmepM mutation suppresses every phenotype of a ΔctpA mutant we have tested (Fig. 5 and data not shown). Uncovering the precise molecular explanations will need more work, but increased cleavage of peptidoglycan cross-links in a ΔctpA mutant might compromise the cell wall, leading to inefficient T3SS function as well as altered cell surface properties that cause the accelerated surface attachment phenotype.

Although E. coli Prc has been implicated in processing PBP3/FtsI (Hara et al., 1991), MepS is the only substrate it has been convincingly shown to degrade (Singh et al., 2015). Therefore, it is not surprising that a ΔmepS mutation suppresses Δprc phenotypes in E. coli (Singh et al., 2015). However, there is a conundrum for P. aeruginosa CtpA. In addition to MepM, LbcA•CtpA degrades at least three more proteins (PA1198, PA1199 and PA4404; Figs. 8 and 9). Like MepM, all are predicted to be DD-endopeptidases that cleave peptidoglycan cross-links (Fig. 9). If up to four peptidoglycan cross-link hydrolases can accumulate in a ΔctpA mutant, why did removing only one of them (MepM) suppress ΔctpA phenotypes? A trivial possibility is that some of these hydrolases are not synthesized and/or active in the conditions in which we monitored ΔctpA phenotypes. Indeed, after growth in T3SS-inducing conditions, the LbcA•CtpA-S302A complex did not pull down any PA1199, and only low amounts of PA4404 (2 and 4 PSMs in two independent samples, see Supplemental Table 1). However, PA1198 was pulled down with comparable abundance to MepM, suggesting that it had accumulated (Fig. 4B), and all four substrates accumulate in a ΔctpA mutant grown in LB broth (Fig. 8A). Another intriguing possibility is that some hydrolases function as part of a multi-hydrolase complex, and removing only one of them destroys the function of the entire complex. The lytic transglycosylases MltD and RlpA were pulled down abundantly by the LbcA•CtpA-S302A trap, but they do not appear to be substrates (Figs 4B and 8A). This could be explained if they interact with MepM and/or PA1198, so that they were pulled down because CtpA-S302A had engaged these substrates. We have not yet been able to make null mutants of all the other CtpA substrates, but addressing their role in ΔctpA phenotypes, as well as investigating the possibility of multi-hydrolase complexes, are exciting avenues for future research.

caption.p: Model: the LbcA•CtpA complex is an important control hub for peptidoglycan cross-link hydrolases. In a wild type strain CtpA forms a complex with the outer membrane lipoprotein LbcA, which is required for CtpA to degrade its targets. The LbcA•CtpA complex has the potential to degrade at least four enzymes predicted to cleave peptidoglycan cross-links (MepM, PA1198, PA1199 and PA4404). This results in crosslink hydrolysis being carefully constrained to limit it to the amount needed for cell elongation and/or division. In a ΔctpA mutant, the activity of MepM accumulates, which might cause excessive crosslink cleavage and subsequent phenotypes, including a defective T3SS and enhanced surface attachment. However, if mepM is deleted from the ΔctpA mutant, the excessive crosslink cleavage is reduced and phenotypes revert back to wild type. It is not yet known if the PA1198, PA1199 and PA4404 substrates make any contribution to ΔctpA mutant phenotypes described in this study. OM = outer membrane, IM = inner membrane.

sec.p: The CtpA substrates MepM (PA0667) and PA4404 are in the LytM/M23 family of peptidases, and both have similarity to E. coli MepM. However, indirect genetic evidence suggests that Prc, the only CTP in E. coli, might not degrade MepM in that species (Lai et al., 2017). E. coli Prc does degrade the NlpC/P60 peptidase family member MepS (Singh et al., 2015). This is notable, because the two other substrates of CtpA in P. aeruginosa, PA1198 and PA1199, are homologous to each other and to E. coli MepS. Therefore, despite being from divergent CTP subfamilies, P. aeruginosa CtpA and E. coli Prc both degrade MepS-like hydrolases. This is perhaps surprising because unlike E. coli, P. aeruginosa has a second CTP, and the other one is a close homolog of E. coli Prc (PA3257, also known as AlgO). The abundance of PA1198 and PA1199 in a ΔctpA prc+ strain (Fig. 8A) suggests that Prc does not degrade MepS-like hydrolases in P. aeruginosa. Another goal for future work is to address this issue definitively by studying the role of P. aeruginosa Prc.

P. aeruginosa Prc was proposed to degrade mutant forms of antisigma factor MucA in isolates from cystic fibrosis patients, causing activation of the extracytoplasmic function (ECF) sigma factor AlgT/U and constitutive alginate production (Reiling et al., 2005, Sautter et al., 2012). Prc has also been linked to AlgT/U activation in strains with wild type MucA (Wood et al., 2006). This is intriguing because the AlgT/U regulon can also be induced by cell wall-inhibitory antibiotics (Wood et al., 2006). Like P. aeruginosa CtpA, and E. coli Prc, it is possible that P. aeruginosa Prc also cleaves one or more peptidoglycan modifying enzymes. Therefore, the impact of Prc on the AlgT/U regulon could be a consequence of altered peptidoglycan rather than Prc cleaving MucA directly. In fact, CtpA overproduction can also induce an ECF sigma factor that can be activated by the cell wall-inhibitory antibiotic D-cycloserine, but CtpA is unlikely to cleave its antisigma factor directly (Seo & Darwin, 2013). Prc has also been implicated in activating several other ECF sigma factors in Pseudomonas species (Bastiaansen et al., 2014). However, induction of ECF sigma factors by cell wall stress is common, and so an effect of Prc on peptidoglycan could perhaps be the explanation. Importantly, Prc has not been shown to cleave any antisigma factor directly.

In summary, we have discovered that a binary protein complex degrades at least four proteins predicted to cleave peptidoglycan cross-links in P. aeruginosa (Fig. 9). Therefore, LbcA•CtpA might be a central hub used to control peptidoglycan hydrolysis, which is a reaction with the potential for catastrophic consequences if it is not carefully constrained. Similarities to the distantly related NlpI•Prc system of E. coli suggest that this is likely to emerge as a widespread phenomenon in diverse bacteria. Given the links between CTPs and virulence in other pathogens, and the importance of peptidoglycan in infectious disease and its treatment, this could have major significance. So far, it has been difficult to investigate when and how degradation of the LbcA•CtpA substrates is regulated, because they are difficult to detect in protease-competent strains (e.g. Figs. 4 and 7). However, even though CtpA and LbcA levels do not change, our preliminary evidence suggests that at least one substrate might be degraded at different rates depending on the growth phase, (D. Srivastava and A. J. Darwin, unpublished data). Investigating how this regulation occurs, and the signal(s) involved, is an exciting question for the future. Other questions include if there is any similarity and/or overlap in the functions of CtpA and Prc; and what are the roles of their proteolytic substrates in P. aeruginosa physiology and virulence.

sec.title: Bacterial strains and standard growth conditions
sec.p: Strains and plasmids are listed in Table 1. Bacteria were grown routinely in Luria-Bertani (LB) broth or on LB agar at 37°C. During conjugation procedures, P aeruginosa was occasionally selected for on Vogel-Bonner minimal (VBM) agar. All P. aeruginosa strains are derivatives of strain PAK (Strom & Lory, 1986). E. coli K-12 strain SM10 was used to conjugate plasmids into P. aeruginosa (Miller & Mekalanos, 1988). Antibiotics were used as follows: ampicillin (200 µg/ml for E. coli), kanamycin (75 µg/ml for E. coli), carbenicillin (150 µg/ml for P. aeruginosa), spectinomycin (50 µg/ml for E. coli and 500 µg/ml for P. aeruginosa), streptomycin (50 µg/ml for E. coli and 250 µg/ml for P. aeruginosa), gentamicin (15 µg/ml for E. coli and 75 µg/ml for P. aeruginosa), and Irgasan (25 µg/ml for P. aeruginosa).

sec.title: Plasmid and strain constructions
sec.p: Plasmid inserts were generated by PCR using standard methods and confirmed by DNA sequencing. In frame deletion mutants were constructed using the sacB+ suicide vector, pEX18Ap (Table 1). Two fragments of ˜ 500bp each corresponding to regions upstream and downstream of the deletion site were amplified by PCR and cloned into the pEX18Ap vector. The plasmids were integrated into the P. aeruginosa chromosome after conjugation from E. coli SM10 and sucrose resistant, carbenicillin sensitive segregants were isolated on LB agar containing 10% sucrose. Deletions were verified by colony PCR analysis. To construct ΔlbcA::aacC1 mutants, the aacC1 cassette from plasmid p34s-Gm (Table 1) was cloned between the upstream and downstream fragments in pEX18Ap, with aacC1 in the same orientation as the deleted lbcA gene. Sucrose resistant, carbenicillin sensitive, and gentamycin resistant segregants were isolated and verified by colony PCR analysis.

To make strain AJDP1140 encoding CtpA-S302A, two ˜ 0.5 kb fragments flanking codon 302 of ctpA were amplified from the P. aeruginosa chromosome. For each fragment one of the primers incorporated a mis-match at the codon 302 region to convert it to encode alanine instead of serine. The fragments were then joined in a PCR SOEing reaction (Heckman & Pease, 2007) via their overlapping regions around codon 302. This fragment was cloned into plasmid pEX18Ap and then used to exchange for the corresponding region of the native ctpA gene by integration, selection for sucrose-resistant segregants and confirmation by colony PCR and DNA-sequencing.

To make strains AJDP1133 and AJDP1153 encoding CtpA-FLAG-His6 and CtpAS302A-FLAG-His6, respectively, two ˜ 500 bp fragments surrounding the stop codon of ctpA were amplified from the P. aeruginosa chromosome. For each fragment one of the primers incorporated a region encoding FLAG-His6. The fragments were then joined in a PCR SOEing reaction via their overlapping FLAG-His6 sequences. These fragments were cloned into plasmid pEX18Ap and then used to fuse the FLAG-His6 encoding region to the native ctpA gene by integration, selection for sucrose-resistant segregants and confirmation by colony PCR and DNA-sequencing of the PCR product.

Plasmids encoding C-terminal FLAG-tagged proteins were constructed by amplifying genes from P. aeruginosa genomic DNA using a downstream primer that incorporated a region encoding the FLAG tag, and then cloning into pHERD20T or pVLT35. Plasmids for protein overproduction and purification were constructed by PCR amplification of genes, without their predicted N-terminal signal sequences and stop codons, and cloning into pET-24b(+) in frame to encode C-terminal His6-tagged versions.

sec.title: Polyconal antiserum production and immunoblotting
sec.p: E. coli strain ER2566 (NEB) containing a pET-24b(+) derivative encoding MepM-His6, LbcA-His6 or OprF-His6 was grown in LB broth to mid-log phase at 37°C with vigorous aeration. Protein production was induced with 1mM IPTG for 4 hrs at 37°C for LbcA-His6 and OprF-His6, or overnight at 16°C for MepM-His6. The proteins were purified under denaturing conditions by nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) affinity chromatography as described by the manufacturer (Qiagen). Polyclonal rabbit antisera were raised against the proteins by Covance Research Products Inc.

Semi dry electroblotting was used to transfer SDS-PAGE separated samples to nitrocellulose. Chemiluminescent detection was done after incubation with polyclonal antiserum or monoclonal antibody, followed by goat anti-rabbit IgG (Sigma) or goat anti-mouse IgG (Sigma) horseradish peroxidase conjugates used at the manufacturers recommended dilution. Primary antisera or antibodies were diluted 5,000-fold for anti-THE-His (GenScript) and anti-FLAG M2 (Sigma), 7,500-fold for anti-MepM, 8,000-fold for anti-LbcA, 10,000-fold for anti-PA0943, anti-PA4068 and anti-CtpA (Seo et al., 2009, Seo & Darwin, 2013) and 20,000 fold for anti-OprF.

sec.title: CtpA-FLAG-His6 tandem purification
sec.p: P. aeruginosa strains were inoculated into 100 ml LB broth to an optical density (OD) 600 nm of 0.05. The cultures were grown at 37°C with aeration for ˜ 5 h until the OD 600 nm was 1.2-1.4, and cells were collected by centrifuging at 6,500 x g for 15 min. For formaldehyde cross-linking, the pellet was washed with ice cold 10 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 8.0 and resuspended to an OD 600 nm of 5 in the same buffer. 1% formaldehyde was added followed by incubation at room temperature for 30 min. 0.3 M Tris-HCl pH 7.5 was added to quench cross-linking and the cells were collected by centrifuging at 6,500 x g for 15 min and 4°C for 15 min. The pellet was suspended in 3 ml lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM Imidazole). Then Roche complete protease inhibitors (2x concentration), 1 µg/ml DNaseI, 1 µg/ml RNase, and 1 mg/ml lysozyme were added. Cells were disrupted by sonication and then 1% n-dodecyl b-D-maltoside (DDM) was added followed by incubation with rotation for 30 min at 4°C. Insoluble material was removed by centrifuging at 13,000 x g for 30 min at 4°C. 200 µl of nickel-NTA agarose equilibrated in lysis buffer was added to the supernatant, followed by incubation with rotation for 1.5 h at 4°C. The resin was collected in a 2 ml drip column and washed with 4 ml lysis buffer, followed by 4 ml lysis buffer containing 20mM imidazole. Proteins were eluted with 1 ml lysis buffer containing 250 mM imidazole and then mixed with 30 µl anti-FLAG M2 agarose resin (Sigma) equilibrated in TBS (10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl), and incubated with rotation for 2 h at 4°C. A 1 ml spin column (Pierce catalog number 69725) was used to wash the resin three times with 800 µl of TBS. Proteins were eluted by adding 100 µl of 2 µg/ml FLAG peptide (F3290 Sigma) in TBS and incubating with rotation at 4°C for 30 min. Proteins present were identified by LC-mass spectrometry analysis (NYU School of Medicine Proteomics Laboratory).

sec.title: CtpA-His6, LbcA-FLAG tandem purification
sec.p: ΔctpA strains containing pVLT35 derivatives encoding CtpA-His6 or CtpA-S302A-His6, and pHERD20T encoding LbcA-FLAG, were inoculated to an OD 600 nm of 0.05 in 250 ml LB broth containing 5 mM EGTA to induce the T3SS. Culture medium also contained 100 µM IPTG and 0.02% (w/v) arabinose to induce protein production. The cultures were incubated at 37°C with 225 rpm rotation until the OD 600 nm was ˜ 1.5. The procedures described in the preceding section were used for protein purification and identification.

sec.title: Analysis of T3SS substrates in cell free supernatants
sec.p: Strains were inoculated to an OD 600 nm of 0.04 into test tubes containing 5 ml of Tryptic Soy Broth supplemented with 5 mM EGTA, and grown for 6 h at 37°C on a roller drum. Cells were removed from the equivalent of 1 ml of culture at OD 600 nm of 1.5 by centrifugation at 3,300 x g for 15 min at 4°C. The supernatant was filtered with a 0.22 µm syringe filter (Millipore) to remove any remaining cells. 1/10th volume trichloroacetic acid was added to the supernatant, followed by incubation at 4°C overnight to precipitate proteins. The proteins were collected by centrifugation at 4,500 x g for 40 min at 4°C. The pellet was washed with 1 ml ice cold acetone, then resuspended in 1 ml of ice cold acetone and incubated for 1 h on ice. The proteins were collected again by centrifugation at 4,500 x g for 40 min at 4°C. The pellet was dried at room temperature for 30-40 min until no acetone aroma remained and resuspended in SDS-PAGE sample buffer containing b-mercaptoethanol. Samples was separated by SDS PAGE (12.5% polyacrylamide) and proteins were visualized by staining with silver.

sec.title: Surface attachment assay
sec.p: Saturated cultures in LB broth were diluted to an OD 600 nm of 0.1 into 13 x 100 mm borosilicate glass tubes containing 0.5 ml of M63 salts supplemented with 1 mM MgSO4, 0.5% (w/v) casamino acids and 0.2% (w/v) glucose. These cultures were incubated at 30°C without agitation for 8 h. The culture medium was removed by aspiration and the tubes were washed twice with 2 ml of water. 500 µl of 0.1% (w/v) crystal violet was added followed by incubation at room temperature for 10 min. The crystal violet solution was removed, followed by two washes with 10 ml water, and then the tubes were inverted for 10 min at room temperature prior to being photographed. Finally, 1 ml of ethanol was added to dissolve the crystal violet and the absorbance of this solution at 595 nm was determined. A tube that had contained the growth medium alone was used to generate the blank. Each strain was tested in triplicate and the error bars in the figures represent the standard deviation from the mean.

sec.title: Subcellular fractionation
sec.p: The osmotic shock procedure to release soluble periplasmic proteins was done as described previously, except that cultures were grown to OD 600 nm of 1.0 instead of 1.5 (Seo & Darwin, 2013). To generate soluble and insoluble fractions from lysed cells, 100 ml cultures in LB broth were grown at 37°C with shaking at 225 rpm to an OD 600 nm of ˜ 1. Cells were collected by centrifugation and washed with 10 ml of 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 20 mM EDTA. The washed cell pellet was resuspended in 10 ml of cold 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 20 mM EDTA containing Roche complete protease inhibitors. Cells were lysed by two passages through a French pressure cell (1,100 psi), and intact cells were removed by centrifugation at 8,000 x g for 10 min at 4°C. The supernatant was centrifuged at 100,000 x g for 1 h at 4°C. The supernatant was retained as the soluble fraction. The pellet was washed twice with 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, resuspended in 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5 containing Roche complete protease inhibitors, and retained as the membrane fraction.

sec.title: CHO-K1 cell cytotoxicity assay
sec.p: Chinese hamster ovary cells (CHO) were grown in Roswell Park Memorial Institute (RPMI) 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 2 mM glutamine, at 37°C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere. For the assay, 2x105 cells/well were seeded in a 24-well plate and incubated at 37°C for 16 h. The attached cells were washed with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and then covered with RPMI 1640 containing 1% FBS and 2 mM glutamine. P. aeruginosa was grown in TSB media at 37°C until the OD 600 nm was 0.8, then added to the CHO-K1 cells at a multiplicity of infection of ˜ 10. The 24-well plate was centrifuged at 250 x g for 5 min and then incubated for 4 h at 37°C. Supernatants were collected after centrifugation at 250 x g for 5 min and the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentration was measured using the LDH Cytotox assay (Promega) according to the manufacturer‘s instructions. All P. aeruginosa strains were tested in triplicate.

sec.title: Cell wall isolation and digestion for LC-MS
sec.p: Bacteria were grown to stationary phase in 500 ml LB broth at 37 °C with 150 rpm orbital shaking. The cells were harvested by centrifuging at 4,750 rpm for 20 min (Allegra X-15R with SX4750 rotor, Beckman Coulter), resuspended in PBS, and sterilized by immersing in a boiling water bath for 60 min. Samples were bead beat (Bead Mill 24; Fisher Scientific) with 0.5 mm diameter glass beads for ten 1 min cycles with 1 min rests in between. Beads and other contaminants were removed using a Steriflip 20 μm nylon vacuum filter (EMD Millipore). Crude cell wall pellets were resuspended in 2 ml PBS, to which 8 ml of 2% (w/v) sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) solution was added, then placed in a boiling water bath for 60 min. Boiled cell wall pellets were washed with deionized water to remove SDS and then resuspended in 2 ml of 50 mM Tris pH 8.0. DNase (200 μg) was added to the cell wall suspension and incubated at 37 °C for 24 h at 150 rpm, followed by addition of pronase E (200 μg) and an additional 24 h incubation. Cell walls were washed once and resuspended in 1 ml of 50 mM Tris pH 8.0.

Isolated cell walls were digested by the addition of 0.5 KU of mutanolysin (Sigma-Aldrich) to the cell wall suspension at room temperature and incubated for 24 h. An additional 0.5 KU of mutanolysin was added to the mixture and further incubated for 24 h. The digested cell walls were frozen and lyophilized (Labconco) and then dissolved in 1 ml of 0.375 M sodium borate buffer (pH 9.0) using HPLC-grade water. Muropeptides were reduced by adding 10 mg of sodium borohydride (Fisher Scientific) at room temperature for 30 min. The reduction was quenched by adding 125 μl phosphoric acid. Reduced samples were frozen at −80 °C and lyophilized. Prior to LC-MS analysis, lyophilized samples were resuspended in 1 ml of sample preparation buffer (1% trifluroacetic acid), centrifuge filtered, and cleaned up for LC-MS using 100 μl Pierce C18 tips (Thermo Scientific).

sec.title: Peptidoglycan analysis by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry
sec.p: Mutanolysin-digested muropeptide fragments were chromatographically separated using a NanoACQUITY Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography System (Waters). A reverse phase BEH C18 column (length of 100 mm and diameter of 75 μm) of 1.7 μm bead with pore size of 130 Å was used. Chromatographic separation of mutanolysin-digested PG was carried out by injecting 2 μl of the sample from a 5 μl sample loop to the column under isocratic condition of 98% mobile phase A (0.1% formic acid in HPLC water) and 2% mobile phase B (90% acetonitrile & 10% of HPLC water added with 0.1% formic acid) for 5 min, then a linear gradient to 50% buffer B was applied for 30 min for the separation. The column was regenerated under isocratic condition with 85% buffer B for 5 min, a linear gradient to 98% buffer A for 1 min, then isocratic at 98% buffer A for 23 min. The flow rate was kept constant (0.6 μl/min) throughout the analysis. Fibrinopeptide B (Glu-Fib) was used as an internal standard to correct for drift of the instrument. Data were analyzed using MassLynx (Waters) and MATLAB (MathWorks).

sec.title: In vitro protease assay
sec.p: E. coli strain ER2566 (NEB) containing each pET-24b(+) derivative were inoculated into 1 L of LB broth to an OD 600 nm of 0.1. The cultures were grown at 37°C with vigorous aeration until the OD 600 nm was 0.6-0.8. Then, protein production was induced by adding 1mM IPTG and incubating for 16 h at 16°C with aeration overnight. The C-terminal His6-tagged proteins were purified under native conditions by nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) agarose affinity chromatography as recommended by the manufacturer (Qiagen). Following elution with imidazole, proteins were buffer exchanged into 50 mM NaH2PO4, 300 mM NaCl pH 8.0, using Amicon Ultra-4 centrifuge filter devices (10 kDa cutoff), and then supplemented with 10% glycerol prior to storage at −20°C. For CtpA-His6 and CtpA-S302A-His6 only, a modification of the manufacturer‘s recommendations was needed to improve protein purity. These two proteins were eluted sequentially with 50 mM NaH2PO4, 300 mM NaCl, pH 8.0, containing 50 mM, 100 mM, 150 mM, 200 mM or 250 mM immidazole. Buffer exchange and freezing was not possible with CtpA due to precipitation. Therefore, CtpA-His6 and CtpA-S302A-His6 were purified, stored at 4°C, and used within 48 h. All experiments were done at least three times with representative experiments shown in the figures.

S.J.K. and B.R. conducted the peptidoglycan analysis and analyzed the data, were supported by the National Institutes of Health Grant GM116130, and also acknowledge the Baylor University Mass Spectrometry Centre (BU-MSC) for support.
